title: Python Virtual Environments
subtitle: Why it is absolutely necessary to work in a virtual environment
excerpt: What to keep your Python projects clean, organized, and bug-free? Learn how to create a "magic coding button" aka. (virtual environment) that keeps your tools seperate and your code happy.
content:
What‚Äôs a Virtual Environment?

Imagine you‚Äôre building with LEGOs. You have one project that needs all red bricks, and another that needs blue ones. What if the bricks got mixed up?

That would be a mess, right? ü§™

That‚Äôs why Python gives you a magic bubble ‚Äî called a virtual environment ‚Äî where you can keep all your special bricks (code tools and libraries) safe for just one project.

Why make a Virtual Environment (Python Bubble)?

Here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs super smart:

  • üß© Each Project Gets its Own Tools You can build different things with different blocks ‚Äî no more mixing red and blue!
  • üßº Keep Your Coding Desk Clean Don‚Äôt let every toy out at once. Only open what you need.
  • üîÅ Share Your Projects Easily When you share your code with a friend, you can also give them the list of tools you used ‚Äî so it works the same way on their computer.

Let‚Äôs Make Your First Virtual Environment (Python Bubble)!

  1. Open the Coding Door (a.k.a. Terminal)

On your computer, open the Terminal (on Mac) or Command Prompt (on Windows). It looks like a black screen with text.

  1. Check if python is installed
# Windows Users
python --version

# Mac and Linux Users
python --version
# or
python3 --version

You should see something like python 3.11.5 in your output. The number/version might be different. But you want at least version 3

If python doesn‚Äôt appear to be installed, you can get a free copy from their website: python.org

  1. Before we make our magic bubble (virtual environment) we need to create a new project folder. In your terminal or command prompt type: (we recommend you be in your documents directory)
mkdir magic_bubble

mkdir: this mean make directory

  1. Create your magic bubble ü´ß
python -m venv venv
# or
python3 -m venv venv

This makes a new folder called venv where all your project‚Äôs magic tools will live.

  1. Jump inside the Bubble and activate ü™Ñ

To use your bubble (virtual environment), you have to ‚Äúactivate‚Äù it.

üçé Mac + üêß Linux:

source bubble/bin/activate

ü™ü On Windows:

.\bubble\Scripts\activate

You‚Äôll know it worked when your terminal shows something like this:

(venv) # or whatever you named the virtual environment

Cool! You‚Äôre inside your virtual environment (bubble)!

üéâ You Did It!

You just made your first Python virtual environment (bubble)! You‚Äôre now ready to create clean, organized, new Python applications.

Testing

Now that we have the virtual environment running. Let‚Äôs start by testing out a custom package. For this test we will use the library: pyjokes

  1. In your project directory with your virtual enviornment activated install pyjokes by typing:
# (venv) $ = is the activated virtual environment. Do not type that.
(venv) $ pip install pyjokes

  1. Once it is installed let‚Äôs create a new simple python app. You can use either the command line or an Integrated Development Environment (IDE). - I will be using the free tool VSCode

  2. In VSCode you might have to open the terminal again re-activate your virtual environment.

  3. In your project directory create a file called: app.py

  4. Then in your app.py file type the following:

import pyjokes

print(pyjokes.get_joke())
  1. Back in your terminal type: python app.py

This should output a random joke in your terminal. You can run this over and over to get a new joke each time.

  1. Let‚Äôs deactivate the virtual environment. In your terminal type:
deactivate

This should remove the text (venv) in your terminal.

  1. Now try running your app again. It should fail because the pyjokes library is not installed in your global environment. It was only installed in your virtual environment.

It is recommended that you always create a new virtual environment for each new project/application.

The final process is to create requirements.txt file that contains all the libraries needed for the project to run.
